review: Worked perfectly ...after 7 days of digging on the internet and talking to dozens of people from Google Chromecast and Actiontec (my Modem/Wi-Fi home DSL network adapter) about the Google dongle and PK5000 (WI-Fi modem). None had a clue on how to make this combo work. It seems like many Chromecast dongles would be returned because of this reason. Also no where did I find a list of DSL modems this WOULD work with.If you have an older modem that the Chromecast refuses to work (and your software and hardware can support it).  I'd recommend this fix. Get a inexpensive Wi-Fi USB dongle like the Cisco AM10 Valet Connector USB Wireless Adapter. And install it. It's about 10 bucks with shipping. All the people I talked with, none had this soultion other than Actiontec wanting me to buy another Wi-Fi modem for 100 bucks.After installing this 10 dollar Wi-Fi dongle onto my system's (Windows 7 home, PC) USB port and then finding the dongle along with the network's name, put in the password and BINGO it worked and it works well for streaming video to my 65 inch Flat screen.I don't know how many people have returned this Chromecast dongle because they didn't know this simple fix or nor did the service departments but it must be many.I'm finally happy.

review: It does work, outside the distribution countries as well. Integration with YouTube is excellent, however casting from the Chrome browser itself seems very dependant on your device specs.For example, from YouTube you have a dedicated casting icon in the video controls. This disables the video on your device, and streams it full screen to your tv. Works well.In the Chrome browser you also have a casting icon, however this effectively casts a mirror of your browsing window (you can still full screen the video). In my case, running an early Acer Chromebook, trying to cast an avi movie from Chrome to my tv is unwatchable.That said, the Chromecast is open for development. Hope to see some solutions soon.
